_**Triadica sebifera**_ , also known as _**Sapium sebiferum**_ , is commonly
known as the **Chinese tallow** ,[1] **Chinese tallowtree** , **Florida
aspen** , **chicken tree** , **gray popcorn tree** ,[2] and **candleberry
tree**.[3] The tree is native to eastern [Asia](/wiki/Asia "Asia"), and is
most commonly associated with eastern [China](/wiki/China "China"),
[Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan"), and [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"). In these
regions, the waxy coating of the seeds is used for [candle](/wiki/Candle
"Candle") and [soap](/wiki/Soap "Soap") making, and the [leaves](/wiki/Leaf
"Leaf") are used as [herbal medicine](/wiki/Herbal_medicine "Herbal medicine")
to treat boils. The plant [sap](/wiki/Sap "Sap") and leaves are reputed to be
toxic, and decaying leaves from the plant are toxic to other species of
[plant](/wiki/Plant "Plant"). The specific epithets _sebifera_ and _sebiferum_
mean "wax-bearing" and refer to the vegetable tallow that coats the seeds.

It is useful in the production of [biodiesel](/wiki/Biodiesel "Biodiesel")
because it is the third most productive vegetable oil producing crop in the
world, after [algae](/wiki/Algae "Algae") and [oil palm](/wiki/Oil_palm "Oil
palm").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] This species is documented as a noxious invader in the southern
U.S.[4][5]

## Physical
characteristics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Triadica_sebifera&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Physical characteristics")]

The simple, deciduous leaves of this tree are alternate, broad
[rhombic](/wiki/Rhombus "Rhombus") to ovate in shape and have smooth edges,
heart shaped and sometimes with an extended tail often resembling the bo tree,
[Ficus religiosa](/wiki/Ficus_religiosa "Ficus religiosa"). The leaves are
bright green in color and slightly paler underneath. They become bright
yellows, oranges, purples and reds in the autumn. The tree is
[monoecious](/wiki/Monoecious "Monoecious"), producing male and female flowers
on the same plant.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/ChineseTallowSeedpods.jpg/220px-
ChineseTallowSeedpods.jpg)](/wiki/File:ChineseTallowSeedpods.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ChineseTallowSeedpods.jpg "Enlarge")

Seed pods

The waxy green leaves set off the clusters of greenish-yellow and white
[flowers](/wiki/Flower "Flower") at bloom time. The flowers occur in terminal
spike-like [inflorescences](/wiki/Inflorescence "Inflorescence") up to 20 cm
long. Light green in color, these flowers are very conspicuous in the spring.
Each pistillate (female) flower is solitary and has a three-lobed ovary, three
styles, and no petals. They are located on short branches at the base of the
spike. The staminate (male) flowers occur in clusters at the upper nodes of
the inflorescence.

Fruits are three-lobed, three-valved capsules. As the capsules mature, their
color changes from green to a brown-black. The capsule walls fall away and
release three globose seeds with a white, tallow-containing covering. Seeds
usually hang on the plants for several weeks. In [North
America](/wiki/North_America "North America"), the flowers typically mature
from April to June and the fruit ripens from September to October.

## Range and
habitat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Triadica_sebifera&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Range and habitat")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Triadica_sebifera_in_the_USA.svg/180px-
Triadica_sebifera_in_the_USA.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Triadica_sebifera_in_the_USA.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Triadica_sebifera_in_the_USA.svg "Enlarge")

Range in the United States

Although native to China and Japan, the plant is also found where it has been
introduced in the southeastern [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States"), [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"), [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan"),
[India](/wiki/India "India"), [Martinique](/wiki/Martinique "Martinique"),
[Sudan](/wiki/Sudan "Sudan"), and southern [France](/wiki/France "France").[6]
Incorrectly thought to have been introduced in colonial times by Benjamin
Franklin, the tree has become [naturalized](/wiki/Naturalisation_\(biology\)
"Naturalisation \(biology\)") from [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina
"North Carolina") southward along the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean
"Atlantic Ocean") and the entire [Gulf coast](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of
Mexico"), where it grows profusely along ditchbanks and
[dikes](/wiki/Dike_\(construction\) "Dike \(construction\)"). It grows
especially well in open fields and abandoned farmland coastal prairie regions
featuring disturbed ground—such as abandoned farmland, spoil banks, roadsides,
and storm-damaged forests—and along the edges of the [Western Gulf coastal
grasslands](/wiki/Western_Gulf_coastal_grasslands "Western Gulf coastal
grasslands") biome, sometimes forming [pure stands](/wiki/Monoculture
"Monoculture").[7] In the [Houston area](/wiki/Greater_Houston "Greater
Houston"), Chinese tallow trees account for a full 23 percent of all trees,
more than any other tree species and is the only invasive tree species in the
14 most common species in the area.[8] The Texas Department of Agriculture
lists Chinese Tallow as one of the 24 most invasive plants, and includes
Chinese Tallow in a list of Noxious and Invasive Plants which are illegal to
sell, distribute or import into Texas.[9][10] Herbivores and insects have a
conditioned behavioral avoidance to eating the leaves of Chinese tallow tree,
and this, rather than plant toxins, may be a reason for the success of the
plant as an invasive.[11]

The plant is sold in [nurseries](/wiki/Nursery_\(horticulture\) "Nursery
\(horticulture\)") as an [ornamental](/wiki/Ornamental_plant "Ornamental
plant") tree. It is not choosy about [soil](/wiki/Soil "Soil") types or
[drainage](/wiki/Drainage "Drainage"), but will not grow in deep shade. It
commonly grows all over Japan, and is reasonably hardy. It is prized for its
abundant and often spectacular autumn foliage.

The tree is common in southeast Oklahoma as well, although it is not depicted
on the map.

## Uses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Triadica_sebifera&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Uses")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/DeerNaraJapan.jpg/250px-
DeerNaraJapan.jpg)](/wiki/File:DeerNaraJapan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DeerNaraJapan.jpg "Enlarge")

_**Sapium**_ _**sebiferum**_ in autumn, Japan

The seed's white waxy aril is used in soap making. The seed's inner oil is
toxic but has industrial applications.

The nectar is non-toxic, and it has become a major [honey
plant](/wiki/Honey_plant "Honey plant") for [beekeepers](/wiki/Beekeeper
"Beekeeper"). The honey is of high quality, and is produced copiously during
the month of June, on the Gulf Coast. In the Gulf coast states, beekeepers
migrate with their [honey bees](/wiki/Honey_bee "Honey bee") to good tallow
locations near the sea.

The tree is highly ornamental, fast growing and a good shade tree. It is
especially noteworthy if grown in areas that have strong seasonal temperature
ranges with the leaves becoming a multitude of colours rivaling maples in the
autumn.

The tree grows well in urban areas, and is very good for "sidewalk holes"
along busy roads with a lot of traffic where most trees will not grow well. It
can provide shade to counter the heat island effect of mainly-concrete areas,
as well as habitat for urban animals such as lizards and birds.

## Invasive
species[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Triadica_sebifera&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Invasive species")]

As aforementioned, the tallow tree is a [non-native
species](/wiki/Introduced_species "Introduced species") to many places around
the world. Its introduced status in North America along with the harm it
causes to ecosystems makes the tree considered an [invasive
species](/wiki/Invasive_species "Invasive species") there. Tallow trees
present a danger of expansion that can hurt local ecosystems by out-competing
native vegetation and creating a [monoculture](/wiki/Monoculture
"Monoculture"). The monoculture would then lower the species diversity and
overall resilience of the area.[12] The tree’s tenacious nature, high growth
rates, and high reproductive ability contribute to its invasive success.
According to the [U.S. Department of
Agriculture](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture "United States
Department of Agriculture"), tallow trees begin producing viable seed in as
soon as three years.[12] They can spread by [root sprouts](/wiki/Basal_shoot
"Basal shoot") and cuttings and are quick to invade after a disturbance occurs
in an area, due to the clearing out of land.[6] A single tallow tree can
produce nearly 100,000 viable seeds annually that can remain in the soil for
several years before sprouting. A mature [stand](/wiki/Stand_level_modelling
"Stand level modelling") can produce 4,500 kilograms of seeds per hectare per
year.[12] These seeds are easily carried to different places by birds and
water. Tallow trees can remain productive for 100 years.[12] It is also
extremely hard to kill—its poisonous features in its leaves and berries leave
it with few to no predators, and its short generation time means even freshly
cut trees can quickly regrow.[6] Currently, [herbicides](/wiki/Herbicides
"Herbicides") and [prescribed fire](/wiki/Controlled_burn "Controlled burn")
are the only effective treatments available to contain and control Chinese
tallow.[6] The USDA is evaluating the flea beetle (_Bikasha collaris_) as a
natural control agent.[13]
